Description: Terracotta lantern in form of seated slave. A lamp-holder for a miniature lamp in the form of a slave boy, seated on sloping ground, waiting for his master, with a lantern beside him. He dozes with his chin on his knees, which he clasps within his arms. The detail is very blurred, but he appears to have the hood of a cloak over his head, pushed back a little way. The receptacle for the lamp forms the plinth, which has a rectangular front with a plain moulding on all four sides; a triangular hole is cut into it to allow the light to shine through. The back of the object is plain, with a rectangular hole for placing the lamp, and a suspension-lug behind the neck of the boy. Hollow; two-piece mould, with added floor and a cut-out in the front of the boy’s lantern. Micaceous (very small particles) brown Nile silt, the front having surviving areas of a white dressing, painted pink, with a little red paint at the base of the lantern.
Curator's comments: BM Terracotta IV Bibliog. Ede n.d.a: 141: lot 42; Vassilika 1992: 272, no. 51.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3541)
